Hutchings and Rainer (1982). The pygidium has a long, pointed terminal process. Specimens from the UK reach about 100 mm and have 140 segments (Hayward and Ryland 1990); specimens from the North Sea are about 180 mm with 150 segments; and specimens from the US East Coast are about 40 mm with 230 segments (Hutchings and Rainier 1982). Some of this size variation could be due to effects of preservation.
